title: calorimetric data
description: Data sets about calorimetric measurements or simulations. In particular, energy fluxes are important.

data.title: The object is used to define calorimetric data.

description.description: This string explains humans the calorimetric data set.

characteristics.title: Characteristics like quasi-stationary or dynamic conditions.

fluxes.description: Energy fluxes between the sample and its surroundings.

conditions.description: Either a measurement aims at quasi-stationary conditions or at dynamic conditions where the values change over time.

componentTilt.description: The tilt angle of the component.

switchableLayers.description: Defines the state of switchable layers.

fluxes.title: Characterize several kinds of energy fluxes towards the sample. Energy flux from the sample has negative values.

conduction.title: Conductive heat transfer is defined by the temperature difference and the heat transfer coefficient.

side.description: The side which is considered for this conduction.

flux.description: The heat flux is driven by the temperature differences. Positive heat flux means heat flux towards the sample. It is measured in watts.

surrounding.description: The average temperature of this part of the surroundings.

sample.description: The average temperature of the part of the sample which faces this part of the surroundings.

coefficient.description: The heat transfer coefficient equals the heat flux divided by the temperature difference. It has the unit watt per square meter per kelvin.

convection.title: Convective heat transfer is defined by the temperature difference and the heat transfer coefficient.

side.description: The side which is considered for this convection.

flux.description: The heat flux is driven by the temperature differences. Positive heat flux means heat flux towards the sample. It is measured in watts.

surrounding.description: The average temperature of this part of the surroundings.

sample.description: The average temperature of the part of the sample which faces this part of the surroundings.

coefficient.description: The heat transfer coefficient equals the heat flux divided by the temperature difference. It has the unit watt per square meter per kelvin.

longwaveRadiation.title: Due to their temperature, bodies emit thermal radiation. Therefore, bodies with different temperatures can exchange energy by this infrared radiation. The wavelength of this radiation is longer than the wavelengths of the solar spectrum. It is therefore called long-wave radiation.

side.description: The side which is considered for this radiative transfer of energy.

flux.description: The energy flux is driven by the temperature differences. Positive energy flux means energy flux towards the sample. It is measured in watts.

surrounding.description: The average temperature of this part of the surroundings.

sample.description: The average temperature of the part of the sample which faces this part of the surroundings.

emittanceSurroundings.description: The emittance of the surroundings influences the radiative transfer of energy. The emittance of the surface of the sample can be defined within `opticalData`. Emittances have no units.

conductionConvectionLongwaveRadiation.title: Energy transfer by conduction, convection and long-wave radiation can be treated together.

side.description: The side which is considered for this combined energy transfer.

flux.description: The energy flux is driven by the temperature differences. Positive energy flux means energy flux towards the sample. It is measured in watts.

surrounding.description: The average temperature of this part of the surroundings.

sample.description: The average temperature of the part of the sample which faces this part of the surroundings.

coefficient.description: The energy transfer coefficient equals the energy flux divided by the temperature difference. It has the unit watt per square meter per kelvin.

shortwaveRadiation.title: Shortwave radiation has similar wavelengths as the visible and the solar spectrum. These wavelenghts are shorter than the wavelengths of `longwaveRadiation`.

flux.description: The irradiance is determined on the surface of the sample. Positive irradiance means irradiance towards the sample. It is measured in watts.

direction.description: The direction of the irradiance on the sample.

mixed.title: Energy flux can be a mixture of the other kinds of energy fluxes. For example, a heat flux sensor may measure the energy flux of solar transmission in addition to the energy flux of convection and longwave radiation.

side.description: The side which is considered for the mixed energy flux.

flux.description: The energy flux is driven by the temperature differences. Positive energy flux means energy flux towards the sample. It is measured in watts.

fluid.title: If heat is transfered to the sample by one or more fluid circuits, this heat flux can be defined by the following properties.

flux.description: This heat flux is caused by the temperature difference between the fluid inlet of the sample and the fluid outlet. It is measured in watts. Positive values mean that heat is delivered to the sample.

inlet.description: The average temperature of the fluid at the inlet of the sample.

outlet.description: The average temperature of the fluid at the outlet of the sample.

massFlow.description: The mass flow of the fluid circuit which enters and leaves the sample in kilogram per second.

specificHeatCapacity.description: The specific heat capacity of the fluid in joules per kilogram per Kelvin.

flux.description: The electric energy supplied to the sample. Positive electric energy means that it is delivered to the sample.

items.description: The current-voltage characteristic can be important for example for photovoltaics. It can also be used just to define just one current and one voltage.

area.title: The component which is used to calculate the results.

category.description: (i) `center` means that the results are valid for the center of the component without influence by the frame. This is important for example for glazings. (ii) `outerDimensions` means that the whole area of the outer dimensions of the component is considered for the results. (iii) `irradiatedAbsorber` means that the area of the photovoltaic or solar thermal absober, which is irradiated by direct irradiance, is used to calculate the results. (iv) For the case of direct irradiance, `projectedIrradiatedAbsorber` projects the directly irradiated absorber area to a plane which is perpendicular to the direct irradiance. (v) If none of the other categories apply, `explanation` below must be used to describe the category.

description.description: If `other` is chosen as category above, the area needs to be defined by this explanation. For any other category, the explanation can add details.

photovoltaic.description: The photovoltaic efficiency of a component which uses irradiance to provide electric power. This efficiency has no units.

solarThermal.description: The solar thermal efficiency of a component which uses irradiance to provide heat.

uValue.description: The U value, also known as thermal transmittance, can be calculated by dividing the heat flux through the sample by the temperature difference between the exterior and the interior.

gValue.description: The g value is also known as Solar Heat Gain Coefficient (SHGC), Solar Factor or Total Solar Energy Transmittance. It has typically values between 0 and 1 and is a measure for the fraction of solar energy which enters the building.

side.description: The name of one part of the surroundings.
